Context:
* George Brown College is building a new 10-storey tall-wood, mass-timber, net-zero carbon emissions building called Limberlost Place. This building will be the first institutional building of its kind in Ontario.
* The building is scheduled to open in summer 2024.
* Jack Cockwell donated $10 million for the construction of Limberlost Place, making it the largest donation to an Ontario college at $18 million with his earlier $8 million donation.
* Limberlost Forest and Wildlife Reserve near Huntsville, Ontario, inspired the name of the building.
* The new building will serve as the new home for the School of Architectural Studies.
* Ontario Lieutenant Governor Elizabeth Dowdeswell, Minister Jill Dunlop, and Toronto Mayor John Tory attended the groundbreaking ceremony on December 14, 2022.
* Cockwell is motivated by his passion for sustainability, the environment, and future generations.
* The building will represent George Brown College's strong commitment to sustainable development with innovative design and extensive use of natural building materials.
* Limberlost Place highlights George Brown College's role as a community-builder and will add to the vitality and modernization of Toronto's beautiful waterfront.

Context:
The new building at Limberlost Place will serve as the new home for the School of Architectural Studies, the School of Computer Technology, and a new childcare facility. It will also house a research hub called the Brookfield Sustainability Institute. The building is designed to be sustainable and innovative, with the ability to generate the same amount of energy it consumes in part through solar energy and deep-water cooling. It will not need to use fossil fuels for heating or cooling.

The project is supported by the federal government and Ontario Minister of Colleges & Universities Jill Dunlop, Toronto Mayor John Tory, and George Brown College President Dr. Gervan Fearon, among others. For more information about the project, visit georgebrown.ca/limberlost.
